type.description: Wallet type: designed for individual users (personal) or for organizations to manage credentials (organizational).

personal.description: Wallet for individuals to store and present their own credentials, such as ID cards or diplomas.

organizational.description: Wallet for organizations to issue, hold, or verify credentials in professional contexts.

capabilities.description: What organizational wallets can do: store credentials (holder), issue new credentials (issuer), or verify credentials from others (verifier).

holder.description: Can store and present credentials to verifiers (holder role).

issuer.description: Can create and issue new credentials to users or organizations (issuer role).

verifier.description: Can request and verify credentials presented by holders (verifier role).

interopProfile.description: Interoperability profiles define standards and protocols that ensure wallets, issuers, and verifiers work together seamlessly across different implementations.

DIIP v4.description: Community-driven interoperability profile based on W3C DID Core and Verifiable Credentials Data Model 2.0 (VCDM), using OpenID4VC and SD-JWT VC for organizational credentials.

DIIP v5.description: Update of DIIP v4 aligned with the current or final versions of OpenID4VCI and OpenID4VP.

EWC v3.description: European Wallet Consortium profile with specification set and conformance approach targeting EUDI Wallet implementations.

HAIP v1.description: OpenID Foundation interoperability profile for high-assurance exchanges, typically combining SD-JWT VC with ISO mdoc.

EUDI Wallet ARF.description: EU Architecture and Reference Framework defining requirements and guidance for interoperable EUDI Wallets.

credentialFormat.description: The technical format in which credentials are encoded. Different formats support different features like selective disclosure, privacy protection, or compatibility with specific standards.

SD-JWT-VC.description: IETF JWT-based format allowing holders to selectively reveal only necessary claims using cryptographic hashing.

mDL/mDoc.description: ISO (18013-5) binary (CBOR) format for mobile documents with strong authentication and selective disclosure.

JWT-VC.description: W3C credential format using JSON Web Tokens for signing and verification.

AnonCreds.description: Privacy-preserving format using zero-knowledge proofs for selective disclosure without correlatable identifiers.

JSON-LD VC.description: Supports rich semantic data with linked data capabilities.

issuanceProtocol.description: The protocol used to issue credentials from an issuer to a wallet. Defines how authentication, credential request, and delivery work.

OpenID4VCI.description: OAuth 2.0-based protocol for securely issuing credentials to wallets.

presentationProtocol.description: The protocol used to present credentials from a wallet to a verifier. Defines how credential requests and presentations are exchanged.

OpenID4VP.description: OAuth 2.0-based protocol for requesting and presenting credentials to verifiers.

identifiers.description: Methods for identifying issuers, holders, and verifiers in credential exchanges. Includes decentralized identifiers (DIDs), HTTPS URLs, OAuth client IDs, and X.509 certificates.

keyStorage.description: Where cryptographic keys are stored: in secure hardware (like TPM or secure enclave) or in software (encrypted storage).

secureEnclaveIos.description: Apple's dedicated coprocessor for storing keys and performing crypto operations on iOS devices.

strongboxAndroid.description: Android's hardware-backed Keystore (StrongBox Keymaster) for key storage on supported devices.

softwareKeyStorage.description: Keys stored in software (e.g. encrypted storage), without dedicated hardware protection.

hsm.description: Hardware Security Module; dedicated hardware for key storage and cryptographic operations, often used in servers.

tee.description: Trusted Execution Environment; isolated area in the processor for running sensitive code and storing keys.

signingAlgorithm.description: Cryptographic algorithms used to sign credentials and presentations, ensuring authenticity and integrity.

credentialStatus.description: How the validity of credentials is checked: whether they are revoked, suspended, or still valid. Different methods use different technical approaches.

license.description: Software license type: open source (publicly available code) or proprietary (closed source).

openSource.description: Source code is publicly available; licensing (e.g. Apache, MIT) defines use and distribution.

proprietary.description: Closed-source software; the vendor retains full control over the code and distribution.

remotePresentationProtocol.description: Protocol for remote (online) presentation of credentials, enabling verification over the internet without physical proximity.

signatureScheme.description: Signature encoding format: JOSE (JSON-based for web) or COSE (binary CBOR for constrained environments like embedded systems).

signatureAlgorithm.description: Cryptographic algorithm used for signing credentials in this interoperability profile.

iso18013_5.description: International standard for mobile driver's licenses with device retrieval (local presentation).

iso18013_7.description: Extension of ISO 18013-5 adding remote presentation capabilities for mobile driver's licenses over the internet.

vcdm20.description: W3C standard data model for expressing verifiable credentials in a secure, privacy-respecting way.

jwtValidity.description: Credential status determined by JWT expiration timestamp.

pkiCertValidity.description: Credential status verified through X.509 certificate validity periods.

ietfTokenStatusList.description: Standard mechanism for representing revocation and suspension status of credentials using status lists.

didWeb.description: DID method using web domains; DID document hosted at a URL leveraging existing domain reputation and TLS security.

didWebvh.description: DID method with verifiable history; extends did:web with version control and cryptographic proof of document history.

didJwk.description: DID method embedding a public key directly in the identifier; self-contained without external resolution.

didKey.description: DID method where the identifier is derived from a public key; compact and self-certifying.

didPeer.description: DID method for peer-to-peer relationships; often used in direct connections between two parties.

didEbsi.description: DID method for the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure; used in EU digital identity contexts.

httpsIss.description: Issuer identified by HTTPS URL; credential issuer metadata and public keys retrieved from a web endpoint.

openidClientId.description: OAuth 2.0 client identifier used in OpenID4VC flows to identify wallets and applications in authorization.

x509Certificate.description: PKI certificate binding an identity to a public key; enables trust through established certificate chains.

joseJws.description: JSON-based signature format for web applications providing integrity and authenticity.

cose.description: Binary signature format optimized for constrained devices and bandwidth efficiency.

ecdsaEs256.description: Elliptic curve signature algorithm providing strong security with efficient key sizes.

Apple Wallet Pass.description: Apple's pass format for storing credentials, tickets, and keys in the Wallet app on iOS and macOS.

Google Wallet Pass.description: Google's pass format for storing credentials and passes in the Google Wallet app on Android and the web.

DIDComm v2.description: Secure messaging protocol for DID-based communication; used for agent-to-agent credential exchange and notifications.

DIDComm v1.description: Earlier version of the DIDComm secure messaging protocol for communication between entities with DIDs.

SIOPv2.description: Self-Issued OpenID Provider; allows the holder to act as an OpenID provider and present self-issued or other credentials.

ISO 18013-5.description: International standard for mobile driver's licenses with device retrieval (local presentation).

BBS+.description: Signature scheme supporting selective disclosure and unlinkable proofs; used in some privacy-preserving credential systems.

ES384.description: ECDSA with P-384 curve; stronger variant of ES256 for signatures and key agreement.

ES512.description: ECDSA with P-521 curve; higher security level elliptic curve signature algorithm.

EdDSA.description: Edwards-curve Digital Signature Algorithm; modern signature scheme (e.g. Ed25519) with fast verification.

ML-DSA (FIPS 204).description: Module-Lattice-Based Digital Signature Standard; NIST post-quantum signature algorithm.

PS256.description: RSASSA-PSS with SHA-256; RSA signature algorithm with probabilistic padding for signing.

RS256.description: RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 with SHA-256; widely used RSA signature algorithm in JWT and certificates.

Bitstring Status List.description: Compact status list where each credential maps to a bit; used for revocation and suspension checks.

RevocationList2020.description: W3C status list format for credential revocation; each entry is a bit in a compressed bitstring.

StatusList2021.description: W3C status list encoding for revocation and suspension; used with Verifiable Credentials.

W3C Verifiable Credentials Status List v.description: Standard status list format for checking revocation and suspension of W3C credentials.
